column1: '''Adûnaic''' ("Language of the West") was the '''Númenórean''' language
column2: spoken by the [[Men]] of [[Númenor]] during the [[Second Age]].

column1: Adûnaic was derived from the [[House of Hador|Hadorian]] tongue
column2: related to the [[House of Bëor|Bëorian]]—collectively called [[Taliska]]. It was more distantly related to the languages of the [[Middle Men]] the east
column3: such as the Men of [[Eriador]] and the [[Northmen]].<ref name=men>{{App|F1ii}}</ref> During the [[First Age]] these languages were much influenced by [[Khuzdul]]
column6: but also by the languages of the [[Eldar]]

column1: Despite being a millennium or more after their separation
column2: the Númenórean mariners who returned to [[Middle-earth]] in the [[Second Age]]
column3: after some close acquaintances they could find common roots and words with the [[Middle Men]] of [[Eriador]] (related to the Folks of Beor and Hador)
column4: and talk about simple matters.<ref>{{UT|Wife}}</ref> This is also partly due to the Númenórean longevity
column5: and the slow change of their language.<ref name=atani>{{PM|Atani}}</ref>

column1: In the western districts of Númenor
column2: the rustic folk still used another dialect
column3: a last remnant of the Bëorian language.<ref>{{PM|XNotes}}

column1: Taliska was not related to the [[Haladin]] tongue at all
column2: therefore the Númenóreans did not recognise the peoples of [[Enedwaith]] and [[Minhiriath]] as their distant kin

column1: Adûnaic was generally considered to be a language of less prestige than the [[Elvish|Elven tongues]]. Most locations of Númenor
column2: and most of the lords and ladies of the [[Dúnedain]]
column3: had also [[Quenya]] or [[Sindarin]] names beside their native ones.<ref name=ak>{{S|Akallabeth}}</ref> Even most commoners knew Sindarin to some degree.

column1: Most of the House of Bëor had been killed after the [[Dagor Bragollach]]
column2: <ref>{{S|Fingolfin}}</ref> but even during the Second Age a Bëorian accent of Adûnaic still survived in parts of Númenor
column3: most notably in [[Emerië]] and around the harbour of [[Andúnië]].
the Númenóreans began to envy the immortality of the [[Firstborn]]
column4: which extended to the languages of the Elves; the Kings and their [[King's Men|followers]] used the Elven tongues less and less. Though the Kings and Queens had all taken their names in Quenya
column5: after some time their supporters used their Adûnaic names to refer to them.

column1: Eventually [[Ar-Adûnakhôr]] took his name in Adûnaic and forbade anyone to speak the Elven tongues in his presence. Adûnaic was now the language of the royal court. Its supremacy was most strongly enforced by [[Ar-Gimilzôr]]: he outlawed the use of Elvish anywhere in Númenor
column2: which antagonized the few [[Faithful]] Númenóreans still living in the land.
his son Inziladûn took a Quenya name again
column4: repealed the ban on the Elven tongues and gave peace to the Faithful. His daughter [[Tar-Míriel|Míriel]] would probably have continued his reforms
column5: but her cousin [[Ar-Pharazôn|Pharazôn]] seized power and
column7: gave her an Adûnaic name (Ar-Zimraphel).<ref name=ak/>

column2: the [[Faithful]] settlers (who controlled the shorelands of the [[Westlands]] from [[Lune]] to [[Pelargir]])
column3: neglected their native tongue and favored [[Sindarin]] and devised names in it; no doubt as a reaction against the rebel Kings who banned the Elvish tongues. This was the case among the Faithful of high lineage who used Sindarin as their native tongue
column4: and became a mark of Númenórean descent
column5: while Adûnaic was left as the daily language of the illiterate
column6: neglected to unheeded change. However some Númenóreans who had Sindarin as their mother tongue
column7: learned this "vulgar" language when it was needed.<ref name=atani/>

column1: With the [[Downfall of Númenor]] came the end of classical Adûnaic. The study and preservation of the language was neglected by the Exiles of Númenor
column2: because they associated it with the rebellious and repressive Númenórean Kings.<ref>{{PM|Dwarves}}

column3: spread from the early Númenórean sailors and colonists
column4: continued to spread as their settlements increased in size and influence and met more peoples
column5: who came under their rule. Those Men of different kinds used this language as a ''lingua franca'' among them. This process became of general importance after the [[Realms in Exile]]; from [[Eriador]] to [[Gondor]] the tongue became widely current
column6: being adopted both by inhabitants and incomers
